column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=4 .
#Text=Feature Extraction
#Text=Feature extraction is one of the main steps in analysing clinical data and a primary key to success in any rule-based or machine learning phenotyping approach .
#Text=Feature extraction can be defined as identifying a vector set that represents efficiently the content of information for a cohort while reducing the dimensionality space .
#Text=Phenotyping systems extract discriminating features to distinguish individuals with a specific condition ( disease ) .
#Text=Feature extraction can be simple and straightforward , such as when using code frequency as a feature .
#Text=Additional features can be extracted by applying some rules on the structured data fields , such as abnormal laboratory lipid levels or the number of visits .

#Text=However , in case the previous techniques fail to increase the accuracy of the prediction systems , NLP is usually applied to extract more features from narrative text . A summary of feature extraction methods is presented at the end of this section .
#Text=4.1 .
#Text=Structured Feature Extraction
#Text=Many EHR structured fields are stored in coded format .
#Text=These fields vary across different institutions ’ datasets . ‘ Diagnoses ’ , ‘ medication ’ , and ‘ procedure ’ fields are the most common types of data represented in code .
#Text=To represent diagnoses , the International Classification of Diseases Ninth Revision ( ICD-9 ) is usually used .
#Text=In representing procedures , the Current Procedural Terminology ( CPT ) is mainly used while RxNorm is utilized to code medication .
#Text=Feature extraction using coded data is available and easy to access and is usually conducted by selecting the code that most likely identifies a cohort with a particular disease .
#Text=However , since coding in EHRs is usually for billing purposes , it is not always sufficient to support clinical research .
#Text=The accuracy of code extraction within an EHR depends on whether the code reflects the physician ’ opinion and whether the physician was able to make a diagnosis correctly .
#Text=In both cases , often the code fields cannot be fully trusted .
#Text=Recently , extracting features from coded fields alone is rarely used , and some additional rules on other structured fields are needed .
#Text=Additional features can be extracted by setting a logical constraint on the structured field data to derive informative features describing phenotype status .
#Text=These features may take different datatypes such as real numbers , true/false or enumerated categories .
#Text=For example , the number of clinical visits , the number of prescriptions and frequency of ICD-9 code can be counted and stored as real numbers .
#Text=The existence of some values , such as medication code , prescription code and hospital admission , can be stored as Boolean values ( 0 , 1 ) .

#Text=The enumerated categories data field can be divided into different subcategories such as ( low , median , and high ) for laboratory results , ( normal , and abnormal ) for blood pressure , or classify patients into certain groups based on age .
#Text=However , in some cases , using structured data alone results in poor predictability in capturing disease cases , making it necessary to look for more features in unstructured fields .
#Text=4.2 .
#Text=Unstructured Feature Extraction
#Text=While structured data are available and easy to access , there are limitations in using these data to describe patients ’ phenotypes .
#Text=Not all diagnoses and symptoms are coded and , therefore , they may offer a weak clue to the patient ’s status .
#Text=Unstructured , or free text EHRs , contain valuable information such as patient history and clinical opinion of this history .

#Text=An analysis of these clinical notes could offer better information and description of the patient ’s status ; however , the manual review of these notes for large-scale projects is costly and highly time-consuming .
#Text=To unlock and extract the hidden information from the narrative text efficiently and accurately , NLP techniques are usually applied .
#Text=NLP is a field of computer-based methods allowing computers to understand and process human ( natural ) language .
#Text=The ability to extract critical components from these data and convert them into a structured format could provide great value for clinical research .
#Text=Narrative text has been utilized to supplement structured data in recognizing particular phenotypes of patients .
#Text=Recent developments in NLP techniques have shown an increasing promise in recognizing and extracting meaningful pieces of information from clinical narrative text .
#Text=NLP techniques automate the processes required to access the large amount of embedded information in EHRs and consolidate the processes into a coherent structure .

#Text=From an Information Extraction ( IE ) perspective , it is essential to pre-process the clinical text by some NLP techniques , such as tokenization , sentence detection , word sense disambiguation , part of speech tagging ( POS ) and parsing .
#Text=Higher-level NLP techniques , such as negation , temporality , and entity relations , are crucial for the precise interpretation of the extracted information .
#Text=Adoption of the previously mentioned techniques varies between reviewed systems and some of these components can be or are omitted .
#Text=For the task of EHR phenotyping , NLP is commonly applied in three different manners : bag of words , keywords search and concept extraction .
#Text=Further details on these techniques are given in the following sections .
